title: Maximizing utility - pretzels and ice-cream cones

content.question: Assume that Larry spends his entire allowance on the purchase of pretzels and ice-cream cones. The price of a bag of pretzels is <math alttext="$1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>1</mn></math>, and the price of an ice-cream cone is <math alttext="$2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">$</mi><mn>2</mn></math>. At his current consumption combination, the marginal utility of pretzels is <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>20</mn></math> and of ice-cream cones is <math alttext="60" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>60</mn></math>. To maximize his utility, Larry should

choices.label: buy more pretzels and fewer ice-cream cones
buy fewer pretzels and more ice-cream cones

content.answer: buy fewer pretzels and more ice-cream cones
